details.title: Accelerated life tests at higher usage rates
details.standardTitle: Accelerated life tests at higher usage rates

p: Guangbin Yang received his Ph.D. in Industrial Engineering from Wayne State University; and M.S., and B.S. in Mechanical Engineering from Zhejiang University, and Hangzhou Institute of Electronic Engineering, respectively. Dr. Yang works at the Ford Motor Company, leading the efforts for reliability design and analysis of on-board diagnostic systems. His work and publications are mainly in developing and deploying methodologies and tools for reliability design, test, and data analysis. He received the IEEE Reliability Society “Engineer of the Year Award” for 2002, and chairs the Automotive Systems Committee of the Society. He has been on the International Program Committee of, and has organized and chaired the invited sessions for, the ISSAT International Conference on Reliability and Quality in Design. Dr. Yang is a Senior Member of IEEE and ASQ. He is listed in the Who's Who in the World, Who's Who in America, and Who's Who in Science and Engineering.

authors.affiliation: Ford Motor Co., Dearborn, MI, USA
authors.name: Guangbin Yang

details.abstract: Accelerated life tests are extensively used to provide quickly the information about the life distributions of products. Test units are subjected to elevated stresses which yield shorter lives. For some products whose life is defined by usage, e.g., mileage and cycles, test units are also run at higher usage rates (UR) to compress the test time. This paper presents a method for testing products at both higher stress levels, and UR. Censoring time is pre-determined and fixed, while censoring usage is a function of UR. A UR effect model is proposed to describe the dependence of usage to failure (UTF) on UR. The relationship between UTF, and stress and UR is established, and used to estimate the UTF distribution at design stresses and usual UR. The model parameters are estimated by maximum likelihood method. The best compromise test plans, which choose the UR, stress levels, and sample sizes, are devised by minimizing the asymptotic variance of the estimator of a life percentile at design stresses and usual UR. The efficiency, and sensitivity of the test plans are evaluated. The results show that the test plans are efficient, and robust.

links.abstract: The undesirable effect of silicone vapor on contact resistance characteristics was examined by using micro relays. From the view-point of vapor transportation and deposition onto the contact surface, the thickness of adsorbed silicone vapor was clarified in conjunction with the formation of SiO/sub 2/. The growth of deposition of silicone molecules was proportional to the exposure time until monolayer formation. context.text: Reference [7], and the author's calculations, show that the experimental region over which \$Var\left[{\hat y}_P(0,0)\right]\$ is minimized reduces to a straight line connecting (0, 0), and (1, 1).

[7] also shows the existence of nondegenerate optimum test plans capable of estimating the model parameters, but because the combinations of factors are generally not rectangular, such plans may not be practical.
The choice is arbitrary; however, it achieves good robustness as well as accuracy [7], [8].

links.abstract: ALT (accelerated life tests) are widely used to provide quickly the information about life distributions of products. Life data at elevated stresses are extrapolated to estimate the life distribution at design stress. The existing estimation methods are efficient and easy to implement-given sufficient life data. However, ALT frequently results in few or no failures at low-level stress, making it difficult to estimate the life distribution. For products whose failures are defined in terms of perf...

links.abstract: This paper deals with optimal design of four-level constant-stress accelerated life test plans with various censoring times. The optimum plans choose the stress levels, test units allocated to each stress, and censoring times to minimize the asymptotic variance of the MLE of the mean (log) life at design stress and test length. A FORTRAN-77 program was written to calculate the optimum plan. This paper compares the test plans with existing three-level test plans, and concludes that: the mean numb...
